MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Heart Surgery Waiting List.

Qst.askee: Minister for Health
Qst.Quest: when a person (details supplied) in County Waterford who has been waiting for two years for heart surgery, will be called for his operation; and in view of the long delay, he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The scheduling of surgery is a matter for the clinical judgment of the consultant concerned and is based solely on the patient's condition and not on the length of time on the waiting list. I have made inquiries from the Mater Hospital and have been informed that the person in question was placed on the waiting list for coronary artery by-pass surgery on 4 February 1992. The hospital is unable at this stage to give a precise admission date for his operation. However, if the person feels that his condition has deteriorated he should contact his general practitioner who would be in the best position to highlight his case to his consultant.

In 1993 I allocated a sum of £1 million from the waiting list fund to enable the facilities to be put in place at the National Cardiac Unit, Mater Hospital to increase the throughput of open heart surgery at the hospital. In addition in 1993, I provided capital funds which will facilitate the doubling of cardiac surgery at Cork Regional Hospital from 200 to 400 patients each year.

The major programme of refurbishment at the National Cardiac Surgical Centre is ongoing. I have allocated in excess of £2 million in 1994 to the Mater Hospital for cardiac surgery and related developments. The development which is nearing completion includes additional cardiac maintenance beds, intensive care facilities and high dependency facilities which are required to support the cardiac surgery programme, including heart transplantation.

This development, together with the developments in progress for cardiac surgery at Cork Regional Hospital, will have the effect of increasing the number of coronary artery by-pass grafts performed on an annual basis in the public hospital sector by 47 per cent.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Transport.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: if she will ensure that persons (details supplied) in County Wicklow who are being denied access to a school bus to bring them to school are granted a bus pass in view of the hardship it is causing and the fact that they cannot gain access to the schools in their catchment areas and are already in attendance in the County Wicklow Vocational School and had a bus pass until they were allocated a council house in Greystones from Newtownmountkennedy, County Wicklow.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The two children in question live in the Bray/Greystones catchment area and their eligibility for school transport relates to the schools in that area.
The family resided in the Wicklow catchment area but in December 1992, because of a fire in their home, they were given temporary accommodation in a location in the Bray/Greystones catchment area.

The elder boy was attending school in the Wicklow catchment area. To avoid disrupting his studies in mid-year, and because of the supposed temporary nature of the arrangement, he continued to be deemed eligible for transport to Wicklow until the end of the 1992-93 year.

In September 1993, when the younger brother started his post-primary education, he was enrolled in the vocational school, Wicklow, even though places were available in Bray, until well after term had started.
My Department has been advised that it is not proposed to move the family from their present accommodation.

MainHeading.P: Therefore, the most that can be offered by my Department is catchment boundary transport to the school they attend, provided they make their own way to the catchment boundary.

Catchment boundary transport is allowed, provided seats are available on an existing service after all eligible pupils have been accommodated. The other proviso is that no exta cost is incurred, either by way of using an extra bus, or by re-routing an existing service.
The question of the eligibility of these two pupils for full transport to Wicklow Post Primary Centre of course will be reassessed if and when they take up permanent residence in that catchment area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 257 and 258 together.

My Department is awaiting reports from its professional advisers on the application for grant aid for repairs to the school building. When these reports have been received and examined a decision in the matter will be conveyed to the school authorities at an early date.

MainHeading.P: There is no record in my Department of an application for a grant in respect of equipment for physical education. The chairman of the board of management has now been invited to submit a duplicate application which when received will be processed at an early date.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Lucan (County Dublin) School Places.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education,
Qst.Quest: in view of the considerable and increasing pressures for post-primary school places in Lucan, she will give her Department's policy on this and provide up-to-date statistical information; if she will commission an independent study on the future requirements for second level education in Lucan, taking into account the present and projected major housing developments in the area; if she will give details on any outstanding applications for additional second level accommodation provisions from Lucan; and if she will make a statement on her strategy for dealing with the growth in demand for second level places in the area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: There are three post-primary schools in Lucan. The following statement, which I propose to circulate in the Official Report, sets out up-to-date statistical details on the post-primary and primary schools in the Lucan area.

My Department has recently received applications for grant-aid towards the provision of additional accommodation at two of the post-primary schools in Lucan — Lucan College and Colaiste Phadraig, CBS. These applications are being assessed at present.

It is not my intention at present to commission an independent study of the future requirements for second-level education in Lucan. However, my Department is carrying out a major review of Lucan and its adjoining areas to determine the short and long term post-primary requirements in the light of current primary and post-primary statistics and taking into account housing developments and other demographic indicators.
